Name: Competition & Regulation
Admission requirements (Germany): Admission to the postgraduate Master's degree in Competition & Regulation LLM requires: 1.) A first professionally qualifying degree in Law or Economic Law in which in-depth legal knowledge was taught; Other degrees in subject-related courses may also be recognised 2.) At least 1 year of relevant professional experience; the following experience is deemed to be of particular relevance: - Full-time eligible (if applicable also voluntary) employment. Employment is deemed to be eligible if it predominantly involved work that corresponds to the qualification level of the relevant degree. - Post-graduate civil service including the economic law aspects. - Subject-related professional training. - Full-time work placement provided that aspects of economic law have been dealt with. 3.) Language proficiency: Applicants must also provide evidence of proficiency in English.
International Office (AAA): International Office Universitätsallee 1 21335 Lüneburg Tel.: 04131 677-1070 Fax: 04131 677-1075

Name: Development Studies
Admission requirements (Germany): Academic requirements: A first (Bachelor's degree or equivalent) university degree in Social Sciences Economics or Business Studies i.e. in one of the following disciplines: Anthropology Demography Empirical Social or Human Geography Sociology Administrative Science Economics Business Studies/Administration or any other equivalent degree with a minimum of 60 ECTS credits in one or several of these disciplines based on a minimum three-year full-time programme. Out of these 60 10 ECTS credits need to come from methods of empirical research such as data collection and survey design qualitative or quantitative data analysis mathematics or statistics. Your overall average mark for your undergraduate degree should be equivalent to 2.5 or better according to the German marking scale or ranked among the best 50% of your cohort. Language requirements: Unless English is your first language or the language of instruction for your undergraduate studies or secondary school education you will need to prove that you have adequate English skills (level B2 CEFR or higher) by means of a recognised language test such as TOEFL with a score of at least 220 (computer-based) 550 (paper-based) or 100 (Internet-based) or an equivalent certificate. Applicants should also have basic knowledge of German (level A1) to make sure that they can organise their everyday life. Applicants who do not yet have basic knowledge of German are offered the possibility to take a language class either before the start of the programme or within the first two semesters.
International Office (AAA): Akademisches Auslandsamt Innstr. 41 94032 Passau Tel.: 0851 509-1160 Fax: 0851 509-1164

Name: Economic Policy
Admission requirements (Germany): 1) To apply for the MEPS programme you need to have an appropriate Bachelor's degree with at least 6 semesters regular period of study. 2) An explicit academic background in Economics is an advantage but not required. Should you have no explicit or only a weak economic background we would like to ask you to especially document that your formal (mathematical and statistical) background is sufficient to enable you to meet the formal requirements of our quantitatively oriented Master''s program. 3) If English is not your first language or if your Bachelor's degree has not been achieved in a program taught entirely in English an adequate command of English (level B1 CEF (Common European Framework) must also be documented. English language qualifications comparable to a 'B1 level' can be documented as follows: - TOEFL test results of at least 550 (paper-based) or 213 (computer-based test) or 79 Internet-based test). - The TOEFL code for the University of Siegen is 8429. - IELTS test with a minimum score of 5.5 points - Cambridge/Oxford Certificate: PET - English language qualifications obtained through at least five years of English instruction in secondary/high school. You are required to enclose copies of your secondary/high school certificates including course and examination descriptions of your English language course for these five years. NOTE: 'NEWSLETTER FOR PROSPECTIVE STUDENTS' Subscribe at www.uni-siegen.de/zsb/newsletter

Name: International Economics and Public Policy
Admission requirements (Germany): 1. Proof of a Bachelor's degree in the subject of economics with a standard period of study of at least six semesters or an equivalent degree in a related subject from a university in Germany or abroad. 2. Proof of English language requirements. This can be provided by presenting a certificate demonstrating the completion of a Test of English as a Foreign Language (TOEFL) which was taken no longer than three years before the deadline for application with a score of at least 227 (computer-based test CBT) 87 (internet-based test IBT) 567 (paper-based test PBT) or alternatively the IELTS (which may also not have been taken more than three years before application) with a score of at least 5 or alternatively a certificate demonstrating the completion of the Cambridge First Certificate (FCE) which was taken no longer than three years before the deadline for application. If one of the above-mentioned certificates demonstrating completion of a language test is not available at the time of application admission may be granted on condition that the certificate together with the test result are submitted by the end of the first semester of studies at the latest. If the proof is not submitted within the deadline or if the test results do not meet the requirements according to No. 2 section 2 admission will be refused. If the degree under No. 2 (or a degree proven to be of higher value) was conducted in English or if the applicant is a native speaker of English this also qualifies as sufficient proof of English proficiency. Proof of native speaker level proficiency must be provided to the Foreign Languages Centre of the JGU by the end of the first semester of studies at the latest. If the proof is not submitted within the deadline then admission will be refused. Examination regulations for the Master's in International Economics and Public Policy 4 (3) In addition a letter of motivation written in English (max. one page) and a CV written in English in tabular form (max. two pages) should be submitted with the application. (4) A further requirement for admission to the Master's in International Economics and Public Policy is that the applicant still has the examination entitlement for this degree course. An appropriate declaration must be presented in accordance with § 10 paragraph 2 section 1 No. 1 and 2; § 10 paragraph 3 section 1 No. 4 and 5 respectively are applicable. (5) If the number of applications that fulfil the admission requirements in paragraph 2 to 3 exceeds the number of study places a special selection procedure will take place. The selection procedure is regulated by the university selection rules of the Johannes Gutenberg University. (6) If proof of having achieved a Bachelor's degree as per paragraph 2 number 1 is not available by the end of the application period the applicant may submit proof of completed exams and academic achievements amounting to at least 135 credit points issued by the responsible institution of higher education or on the basis of preliminary certificate of recognition of the JGU for foreign degrees. If the course is subject to admission restrictions the provisions of the current version of the university selection rules and the regulations for foreign students must be observed; in this case the final result of the Bachelor's degree will not be considered for the selection procedure. If an applicant is selected based on the certification listed in section 1 admission is granted on condition that the degree certificate is presented within the period stated in the letter of acceptance.  If the certification is not presented by the deadline the admission will be cancelled. (7) Command of German is not required for the Master's in International Economics and Public Policy.
International Office (AAA): Abteilung Internationales Forum universitatis 2 55122 Mainz Tel.: 06131 39-22281 Fax: 06131 39-25548
